"uncomfortable saying no to a request from a professor"
I'm reminded of the Zimbardo experiments, where students "shocked" other subjects, and as fake guards abused other student "prisoners", just because the professor created a situation where it was "allowed".
Are there any comparison studies of the impact on learning of IMAGINING doing these actions vs actually doing them?

Not mentioned is the purpose of this particular class (as opposed to the author of the study guide). I'm guessing it was to experience a visceral reaction to the action, and possibly to see how many students would refuse the task. What was the ensuing discussion like? Did the complaining student voice his objections then?

Did he take the exercise as stepping on Jesus? Seems like he (and a lot of other people) can't distinguish between a symbol and the real thing. If this was a philosophy class, he flunks.

My first reaction is to point out that the student had the option to say no. Then I remember that a student may be uncomfortable saying no to a request from a professor, even if they know that saying no is a valid option. Then I finally remember that being asked to confront uncomfortable situations is an important part of college. If over the course of four years in college you never experience an uncomfortable collision with your principles, your degree is unlikely to be worth its paper.

By the way, are you aware of the practice of fumi-e, the images of Jesus upon which Japanese people were obliged to step, reluctance to do so revealing oneself as a (then-illegal Christian)? This whole scenario is reminding me of that tactic.
Thought provoking. We never hear about these people's struggles in newspaper articles. They are almost invisible.

Quite a few older Japanese with important job skills are finding employment in China. The mood in Japan might be somewhat subdued and even grim for a lot of people, but China has energy and a new pride. Malaysia is another example of where life is good. The optimism that one feels in Malaysia is striking.

Japan is good at reinventing itself, and they certainly need it. Murakami said that Japan discovered hope after Fukushima. On the contrary, what they should have discovered was a puffy self-interested government concerned only with leaders looking out for themselves.

I think it is noble that this young woman is able and willing to give so much of herself, but what happens when she has her own family and obligations. We are asking teachers to be the parents that these students need and lack, but what of teacher's own lives? I think , and mabye it is because I am giving them the benefit of the doubt, some teachers get to a point in their lives were they have to consider how much of their own families and lives must they sacrifice on the off chance one of their students might appreciate it.
It is really unfair to ask people to be parents to kids who dont care and still expect these teachers to continue to be enthusiastic and generous with their time, money and energy.
Again, it is wonderful this young lady can do it and I hope she never gets discouraged. I hope her students appreciate that a stranger has decided to invest so much in them, when their own parents can't, don't or won't.
Karoshi has actually also come to include suicide in how people describe it.
please note that karoshi is the official term in Japanese for death from overwork, NOT suicide.  Karoshi is a legally recognized "cause of death" in Japan.

Love Japan, and the Japanese, and lived in Tokyo for all of 1990 and three years, 1994-1996. Studied the language for four years, and marveled at the way they handle personal sacrifice and appreciate the small things (like space) in life. The 90's were the "Lost Decade" and 1990 saw a sudden end to a go-go, flamboyant period, and attitudes didn't change right away so the very upbeat, energetic spirit remained in place for awhile. But, really - 1/3 of the workforce is now temp workers with no benefits? If so, that, plus the sad but poignant portrayal in this slideshow (us Americans could never pull this off) indicates a slide in standard of living for many Japanese, from overwork for those [un]fortunate to have it, and limited opportunities for young women. I don't think you will find this same situation in, for instance, South Korea, today.

There are as many officially recognized cases of work-induced suicide in Japan each year as there are recognized deaths from heart disease or stroke. It is called karojisatsu. The official figures on both types of death from overwork understate the true toll. In spite of increased consciousness about karoshi and karojisatsu, few Japanese people have the courage or resources to file claims in these cases.
"Karoshi" means death from overwork - often from a heart attack or stress-induced stroke - not "suicide."

You totally establish the reality of this profession.  A primary function of a Principal is to teach a teacher how to teach.  A crash course in pedagogical preparation is a band aid approach, an artifice,,,superficial.  The craft of teaching is combination of of instructional method and the art of applying techniques that address a particular issue or specific subject; while identifying and meeting the needs of the individual.  This requires adequate supplies, appropriate class grouping and reasonable class register.  Administrative support providing instructional models is a component of a support system.  Arriving at work hours before class time is indicative of much more than dedication.  Actually, an unattended school…without security, and administrative presence represents a relatively dangerous environment; relative to liability and personal safety.  The teacher has adequate time to prepare lessons during preparation periods and  post school hours. A public library or a home office is a suitable and safe environment for lesson planning. and preparation.

For good schools you must start with a supportive administration, who came up through the ranks, in classrooms teaching academics, not business managers we have today, and who excelled, who know how to teach a teacher how to teach, in a supportive, not punitive way, and then you need proper supplies and tools, you can't build the 2nd ave subway without sufficient workers, tools, money etc.  same as in a school, they need books, computers, equipment, and no school should be favored over another, because of neighborhood etc. there should be equal distribution of funds and materials.  I think with a really exceptional administration, which most schools don't have,, schools would have the leaders that make the best decisions, that support their staff, guide them, handle parents well, inspire students, and know which materials and tools are necessary.  This can be done, start with good administrators, who were great classroom teachers.  Not just with an administrative license.

"and with the riot at Stonewall in 1969, and since, for gays."

Um, yes, and before 1969. Persecuting gays has a very long and detailed history, it didn't start in 1969.

Few now can relate to the trouble of being Irish. But when I was a boy I heard the older generations' stories. And I read. And what I learned made me sensitive to all who suffer for what they are, and are taught is inferior: women, Blacks, Native Americans, Japanese during WW II, and with the riot at Stonewall in 1969, and since, for gays.

Irish suffering is distant now. Most can't conceive how it can be compared to that of apartheid or women's rights or the suffering of Blacks and Gays and the North Americans we corralled onto reservations.

But I learned from it to take on myself the suffering I learned that ancestors felt and the anger that came with it. Not anger as fury, but as resolve, to resist, to speak up, to push when pushed, to assert, and in the end to win what is right to have.

Many of us are "The Elephant Man," in the end, really, visibly, or in the case of Gays in plain sight, but invisibly.

On April 24, 1916, Padraig Pearse calmly walked to the flagpole at the GPO in Dublin and raised the green flag of the Irish Republic. He and 1,200 others had started The Rising. He told his mother when he left her that Monday he wouldn't be back. The British executed him in May for his actions, after smashing the rebels.

But six years later most of Ireland was free for his boldness and Irish everywhere were watching.

The first Gay athlete won't be executed. But it may seem as difficult.

Millions of us are enlisted in his army, and he shall overcome.

I had a similar job in a similar place for 25 years.   Remediating a disruptive student is a challenge  However, I was forbidden from expelling a child from the classroom.  Forbidden is an understatement.  In my era (and possibly today) the theory is a child must remain in the classroom in order to be educated.  A guidance counselor was a luxury and an exception.  I submit  this still is the case.  Guidance counselors have daily program  of cases and are usually   unable to intervene.  If I expelled an unruly child from class who would supervise the child in the hallway?   The Administration would look unkindly to the expulsion .  I would be subject to  disciplinary consequences.  Having gone on with this….I might add allowing an acting out student to disrupt the learning process of the entire class is a  terrible condition.  It drains the teacher of energy and deprives the class of instruction.  Frankly, I place responsibility for  containment in extreme cases upon the school Administration,  Those Principals' offices are awfully comfortable and insulated environments.   It takes a lot for a Principal….who, by the way, has a support staff of department chairs, deans and assistants….to leave the comfort of their protected environment..  It's more challenge for a Principal to structure  positive activity to correct  a behavior, maintain supervision and continue learning activity.   In my day the answer was simply to chastise the classroom teacher as inadequate.
